comment_text: I really appreciate this video. Honestly, I started avoiding COVID news after a while. I see the headlines and immediately get repelled. For the most part, it comes from a want to ignore the possibility my life is at a stand still and that the reality of my senior senior high school year is that I am living in a (probably) once in a life time that make things just...different. I’m already struggling with mental health and existentialism, and the general tone all over the news is so much alarm and outrage that I just get so tired easily. There is almost no one who has talked like this. Calm. Patient. But firm. This may be reality, but we will be okay one day.
Thank you.

We are not doing enough.
What happened with those covid apps? Everybody needs to install at least one, to make contact tracing easier. Also double check if location history is enabled in google, the more places your location info is the better.
It helps to be prepared, take at least two masks with you when you go out, in case one gets compromised. I also carry a bottle of water and soap, so I can wash my hands immediately after going into a shop for example. Better safe than sorry.
Remember to notify the authorities when you see garden parties or someone violating their quarantine.
I also carry a selfie stick to enforce social distancing when people try to get too close. I'm not squeamish, but everytime I smack someone with the stick, or force a mask on an anti-masker I have to remind myself that it is for the public good and I am helping them.

I got Covid way back in April (13th), and while it didn’t affect me and my girlfriend as bad as it did others, I still have certain symptoms that never really went away.

It’s been half a year now and I hope people realize that just because it won’t kill you specifically (if you’re one of the lucky ones) it might cause you to have a different quality of life afterwards.
Some people have some respiratory issues where they feel like their breathing isn’t all what it used to be, or headaches, brain-fog, aches elsewhere on their body.

Please be careful out there.

When you touch on issues of mental health, for your series on public health, please, please, please be deliberately careful in your research, and speak to the communities that are affected by mental illness. There is, unfortunately, a severe problem of ableism within the medical community toward mentally ill people. At least with regards to autism, I urge you to avoid using Autism $peaks as a source of any information. They are considered by the autistic community to be a hate group. ASAN would b a good place to start, for when you get to that area of public health and autism, specifically. I worry about how people present those issues.
this is history, which will remember as time when we were washing our hand, wearing mask and keeping social distance
I've been self-isolating sine January. I've only gone outside of my home maybe two times per month on average. It's been a ride. But it's important.

I work for the national heath service in the uk. As you would expect, there is a culture of "follow the rules" in hospitals. If I were to be seen walking down the corridor with no mask on, or not be seen to be washing my hands after patient contact, I would not only risk my job, but lose the respect of people I like and respect. I've come into close and prolonged contact with many covid positive patients since March this year, as have all of my colleagues. I've been coughed and sneezed on (unintentionally) by covid positive patients. But I've not fallen ill with it yet, and nor has any one of the colleagues I know personally. I know people who know people who caught it from work, but don't actually know anyone who has. Many (more than half) of my colleagues are from demographics considered at higher risk of catching it. The only rational explanation I can think of for the low infection rate of staff where I work, is that taking the required precautions actually works.

I always try to remind myself that there are 2 truths about the pandemic experience:

Every single person is feeling the impact, it is a global phenomenon
It impacts everyone differently, no two people are facing the same combination of challenges

This is a difficult time for everyone, but some people are having a harder time than others, and while we may feel powerless to stop the pandemic, there are things we can do. Just as importantly, we can still help each other, and we need to continue to help each other

It's an important message. Thing is people who are not abiding by relatively low impact ways of limiting spread likely won't hear the message and now think "oh, yeah i should do that" They've already heard that multiple times and by this point every time that's uttered makes people dig in their heels even more. I work as a non-medical personnel in a clinic and it's so tiring to keep saying to people: "sir you might not noticed but your mask slipped down from your nose" giving them the opportunity of acting as if it was an accident not a deliberate choice. And i have to limit how much I can utter those words in a set period of time so that people won't notice that it's just a line. And this is in a healthcare facility. In grocery stores we had multiple assaults for asking to wear a mask. This is all so tiring such a downer to see people in society not performing minimally inconvenient actions to protect others.

So basically I've been living a variation of stage 4 lockdown since March 2020. I work from home, my social bubble is limited to two (me and my partner), I have never broken this bubble (I have not seen friends or family in person since this began). We've lost two people close to our family from covid and from the situation covid created. My partner goes into work 1 day every two weeks, where she is exposed to no more than three people who comply with physically distancing and no in person meetings (she goes to do isolated physical work). We wear masks in the common areas of our apartment building and anytime we find ourselves needing to go into a store (approx. once every two weeks).

We are in a good position to do this, relying on savings to supplement any loss of income and living in a place where our government supports our efforts.

I am increasingly becoming concerned, like health officials in the early days, that the reliance on masks makes us less diligent about the other, more effective measures to slow the spread of this disease.

What does everyone else think?

It’s strange to think that we’re living through history as we speak. For all my life, it’s just felt like things haven’t really changed and everything else was a short fluctuation before a return to the status quo. That was until 2016, at least, when I finally realized the status quo was beginning to buckle in on itself. Come 2020, and humanity (or at least the small subsection which lives in America) are stuck between a rock and a hard place, with the largest pandemic sweeping across the world since Spanish Flu, and an election that seems like it may scar the nation regardless of the victor. I hope things can return to whatever we call “normal” now, but a part of me knows that this may just be the first part of a new chapter of history. Perhaps in the future, Robot John or someone else will read through this comment when researching how people felt during this pandemic, and quote it in a Crash Course on 21st century history. That, or it’ll be lost to the sands of time. I’d say it’s about 50/50 odds on that one.

This weekend I (virtually) attended a medical conference about a disease I and millions of other young people live with, and it was so disheartening to hear about how much medical research is currently on hold in countries where the pandemic is out of control (like the United States).

People have been telling me that all the vulnerable people just need to stay home while “the rest of us” get on with our lives. Not only is that not feasible (4 in 10 Americans have a condition that makes them more vulnerable to COVID-19 complications), and not only does that ignore the tremendous death toll, but it also doesn’t see the whole picture of what’s being put on hold when this virus continues to run rampant. You may be going about like normal, but behind the scenes the future of disease research is at stake. We, all of us, need to be doing all that we can to halt or dramatically slow the spread of COVID-19. Thanks for this video.

Obviously, the logical scientifical conclusion when a particular disease is affecting certain minorities all_around_the_world is that social injustice is to blame, not genetics and certain factors like the low levels of Vitamin D.

I work  as a telecommunication contractor and go all over the place. Some of clients are rehabilitation and senior living facilities. The old feeble people I see need this clean environment because God forbid they have to live another day soaking in there waste waiting for death. Everywhere else I go it's maditory to wear a mask, sometimes put on a medical gown, gloves or even place my tools in a plastic bag.  And I laugh at the fear people have or their newly reprogrammed behavior (Karen's). I so hate being forced to do something I don't agree with. It's just a virus. Wash your hands. Don't touch your holes. Stop shaking hands. Wear a mask if you want or live in a bubble. When I go home  away from the city in a deep rural setting, we all have had covid, utility guys, convince store workers even the local co-op company everyone is fairly sure they've had it. No one died btw. Only a handful wear mask, mostly the weak and feeble. Take off the mask, go back to work. Let it run it's course. If you are weak or feeble, stay home or suit up, but stop forcing me to bend to your fears. I love Crash Course and John and Hank and all the people behind the curtain. Carpe diem.

I’m a law student, a terrible decision I wouldn’t wish on my worst enemy, and my law school shut down for half the spring semester and was distanced over the summer. I’m living with an immune compromised roommate, and he means the world to me. I managed to get my fall schedule be distant this semester. Every week I get emailed about more students and staff catching the disease because they’ve not been social distancing at the school. But people were lonely, so they reopened by popular request.

This is a scary time. As much as I hate being in law school, I love how much I get to hate law school, together, with my classmates. They’re good people, and good friends. Things are different now, it’s nice to be reminded that things will, slowly, one day, be better than they are today. Thanks crash course.

Also, I used your IP series as a study aid for my summer IP class, and it really helped me pass, so thanks for that too, it means a lot. I’m not going to ask for Crash Course: Bar Prep, but I wouldn’t complain either.

It would be good if a episode was dedicated to comparing different mask types. For example: I wear a ventilated dust mask with a carbon filter, but have to wear a loose N95 when visiting medical facilities. One thing I noticed is that my glasses heavily fog over when wearing the medical mask. The medical mask is made out of special materials that more effectively catches droplets, but I have the impression the loose fitting allows vapor to pull a maginot line.

Having a scientific guide to mask types would be a good PSA.
